newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft, Intuit, Checkfree in Net banking pact.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft, Intuit, Checkfree in Net banking pact.

text.p: Microsoft Corp. and Intuit Inc., formerly rivals in the Internet consumer banking sector, will unveil Thursday a common specification for online banking and financial transactions, industry analysts said Wednesday.
The so-called "Open Financial Exchange" will create a common platform for electronic banking for banks that want to offer home banking to customers.
This will allow a direct link over the Internet between consumers, using Intuit's Quicken or Microsoft's Money personal finance software, and their financial institutions.
CheckFree Corp., which purchased Intuit's online processing unit last September, will provide the bill processing and payment component, they said.

"They all have been writing to different specifications for people to plug into their software or their services," said one analyst familiar with the agreement. "Instead of going in separate directions, they are going in a single direction."
The three firms have scheduled a conference call for Thursday morning to anounce the agreement.
A Microsoft spokesman refused to comment on details of the call. Neither Checkfree nor Menlo Park, Calif.-based Intuit were available for comment.
Gary Arlen, President of Arlen Communications, said Intuit and Microsoft had been working on the standard for two months.
"They got together in November and have emerged with a common platform that can be used for home banking ... so that banks who want to offer home banking won't have to choose between these two."
Arlan said the platform will remain open, and that the companies were inviting other firms to create software that supports what could be a de facto Web banking standard.

In May 1995, Microsoft's plans to buy Intuit were scuttled by the Department of Justice, and the Redmond, Wash.-based software giant has since earmarked a large portion of its research and development budget for financial software and online banking services.
But Intuit's Quicken remains the market leader with about 70 percent of the market.
